Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Diversifying the STEM Labor Force: Are Women and the Foreign-Born Complementary or Additive?

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Award.AbstractNarration:
The need for STEM workers is expected to grow at or above the national growth rate over the next decade (U.S. Department of Commerce, 2012). In recent decades the U.S. government has focused a good deal of attention on increasing the presence of women and underrepresented minorities in STEM fields. The science and technology labor force has already diversified in important ways over the past few decades. Women's representation in science and technology education and employment has increased significantly, though their representation remains considerably smaller in fields such as engineering and computer science. This research explores whether the particular components of the STEM labor force - such as the representation of women in particular fields, or the share of coworkers of a particularly nativity or race - are associated with retention in the STEM work force or the gender wage gap. In fields where women account for a larger representation of STEM workers, for example, is the gender wage gap narrower? How is that relationship influenced by the group size of foreign-born workers, and does it matter whether these workers received their education and training in the United States or abroad?

There are several social scientific views that can be evoked in seeking to account for the dynamics involved in occupational sex composition and occupational wage rates. These perspectives are not necessarily mutually exclusive, but each focuses on distinct ways in which employers may exhibit preferences by gender or ethnicity. Our project will utilize Queuing theory and Devaluation theory to explore how the changing composition of the STEM labor force promotes (or retards) the retention and earnings of women in STEM. Such an approach will enable us to move beyond a simple gender dichotomy (men/women) to assess variation within gender (native-born/foreign-born). Data come from pooling six waves of the National Science Foundation's (NSF) Scientists and Engineers Statistical Data System (SESTAT), covering years from 1995 through 2008. SESTAT is comprised of three ongoing surveys designed to create a nationally representative sample of science and engineering college degree holders (Kannankutty & Wilkinson, 1999). The restricted SESTAT data include detailed information regarding labor force participation, occupation categories, educational attainment, and demographic characteristics. The proposed project will include three sets of analyses, including descriptive analyses establishing trends in STEM employment by gender and nativity, as well a time since degree; multivariate logistic regression models incorporating predictors of employment in a STEM profession, by sex, and how group representation of the foreign-born moderates these associations; and OLS regression of women's and men's logged wages on observable characteristics.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project used data from the National Science Foundation's (NSF's) Scientists and Engineers Statistical Data System (SESTAT) to study gender and nativity differences in employment in STEM occupations among college graduates who hold a STEM degree.  We took advantage of the large-scale nature of the data to examine how gender and group representation in a given field of study was associated with subsequent retention in the field, wages in that field, and transitions out of the STEM labor force. Our major goals were to assess  (1) gender and nativity differences in STEM employment and earnings; (2) employment and earnings differentials between native-born and foreign-born STEM workers by gender; and (3) the degree to which the group size of foreign-born STEM workers influences women's employment and earnings in STEM occupations.  

After exploring the gender wage gap in STEM fields in the SESTAT data, the fields with the most notable wage gaps as well as lower female occupational representation were computer science and engineering. This is positive news for women in the life and physical sciences, where the majority of women in STEM are trained and where most laboratory research occurs. However, these are not the dominant employers of STEM-trained workers overall.  We therefore decided to focus on computer science and engineering, the two areas that employ about 80% of those who work in STEM, to better understand the factors shaping wage growth and retention.

Our assessment of the factors accounting for retention in full-time jobs across computer science and engineering show that different factors are associated with persistence in these two occupations. Conditional on receiving a degree in computer science, women are 14 percentage points less likely to work in STEM than their male counterparts. Controlling for demographic and family characteristics did little to change this gender gap. Women with degrees in engineering are approximately 8 percentage points less likely to work in STEM than men, although about half of this gap is explained by observed differences between men and women. We document a widening gender gap in STEM employment in computer science, but this gender gap narrows across cohorts among those in engineering. Among recent computer science graduates, the gender gap in STEM employment for white, Hispanic, and black women relative to white men is even larger than for older graduates. Gender and race gaps in STEM employment for recent cohorts of engineering graduates are generally small in comparison. 

Given these findings, we are now calculating field specific measures of group size (by nativity and gender) to assess whether relative group size affects the gender representation and wage gap in engineering and computer science. In particular, we seek to understand whether STEM-trained women find themselves used as a lower waged alternative to native-born men, as foreign-born workers frequently are used in technology firms.  We are also exploring where those trained in these fields go to work when they leave computer science or engineering jobs. We are looking to add in more recent data (from 2010 and 2013) to update our results as well. 

Because our results suggest that women face a more challenging climate in computer science than engineering, our future work will dig deeper into the data to better understand what is going on with computer science, exploring whether women are more likely than men to leave computer science jobs, and if so what kinds of jobs they take and whether they receive higher or lower earnings in their new jobs.
